text: Good morning. Today is Monday, July 24.

I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR News, 
and here are today's top stories:

Lawmakers in the Israeli Parliament 
have passed a controversial judicial

reform bill. The measure has drawn 
fiery condemnation from opponents,

who say it will significantly damage Israel's 
democracy. Supporters in the ruling party say

they want to stop the Israeli Supreme Court from 
overreaching. There is so much fury about the

judicial reform legislation that some members of 
professional groups, such as doctors, have gone

on strike briefly. Some military reservists 
in Israel have said they won't work either.

Today is the deadline for Texas Gov. 
Greg Abbott to respond to the Justice

Department over floating barriers in the 
Rio Grande. As Texas Public Radio's David

Martin Davies reports, the federal agency 
is threatening Texas with legal action:

"Last week, the Biden administration sent the 
Texas governor's office notice that it wanted

to enter into negotiations over the removal of 
the buoy barrier. Abbott ordered the floating

wall placed in the middle of the river separating 
the United States and Mexico to prevent migrants

from illegally crossing into Texas. The 
DOJ says the buoys violate federal law,

raise humanitarian concerns and present 
serious risk to public safety and the

environment. The buoy wall is the latest 
development in a growing battle between

Republican states and the federal government 
over the border and immigration. Abbott signaled

on Twitter he is not backing down, writing 
'We will see you in court, Mr. President.'
"I'm David Martin Davies, in San Antonio."

A new survey from the National Association for 
Business Economics shows considerable optimism

about the U.S. economy. Steve Beckner 
reports those results run counter to

speculation over the past year that the U.S. 
economy was in risk of going into recession:

"Actual business conditions are turning out 
better than many had feared. NABE President

Julia Coronado says the survey of her 
members 'reflects an economy of rising

sales and profits.' The business economists 
say their firms were able to increase prices

at the same time their material costs fell 
and upward wage pressures lessened. Coca-Cola

Chief Economist Carlos Herrera, who chaired the 
NABE survey, says the resulting brighter profit

outlook means most firms in the group are now more 
confident about the economy over the next year.
"For NPR News, I'm Steve Beckner."

The National Weather Service says 
excessive heat is sticking around

much of the U.S. today. Millions of people, 
mostly in the central U.S. and the West,

are under heat advisories or warnings. 
Forecasters caution the dangerous heat

will spread to much of the eastern 
two-thirds of the country this week.

Search teams in Pennsylvania are 
concentrating their efforts to

find a missing baby. He was swept away in a 
flash flood north of Philadelphia more than

a week ago. That flood killed six people, 
including his mother and 2-year-old sister.
This is NPR.
